Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of SuperMIC -- A Heterogeneous Computing Environment to Enable Transformation of Computational Research and Education in the State of Louisiana

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: This is an award to acquire a compute cluster at LSU. The computer is a heterogeneous HPC cluster named SuperMIC containing both Intel Xeon Phi and NVIDIA Kepler K20X GPU (graphics processing unit) accelerators. The intent is to conduct research on programming such clusters while advancing projects that are dependent on HPC. The efforts range from modeling conditions which threaten coastal environments and test mitigation techniques; to simulating the motions of tumors/organs in cancer patients due to respiratory actions to aid radiotherapy planning and management. The burden of learning highly complex hybrid programming models presents an enormous software development crisis and demands a better solution. SuperMIC will serve as the development platform to extend current programming frameworks, such as Cactus, by incorporating GPU and Xeon Phi methods. Such frameworks allow users to move seamlessly from serial to multi-core to distributed parallel platforms without changing their applications, and yet achieve high performance. The SuperMIC project will include training and education at all levels, from a Beowulf boot camp for high school students to more than 20 annual LSU workshops and computational sciences distance learning courses for students at LONI (Louisiana Optical Network Initiative) and LA-SiGMA (Louisiana Alliance for Simulation-Guided Materials Applications) member institutions. These include Southern University, Xavier University, and Grambling State University - all historically black colleges and universities (HBCU) which have large underrepresented minority enrollments. The SuperMIC cluster will be used in the LSU and LA-SiGMA REU and RET programs. It will impact the national HPC community through resources committed to the NSF XSEDE program and the Southeastern Universities Research Association SURAgrid. The SuperMIC will commit 40% of the usage of the machine to the XSEDE XRAC allocation committee.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project has developed and deployed the HPC cluster, SuperMIC, consisting of 382 computing nodes and providing 1 Petaflops of peak performance by utilizing two Intel Xeon Phi 7120P accelerators in each computing node. 

After the LSU project team deployed the HPC SuperMic, SuperMIC has supported large-scale scientific and engineering applications at LSU and the HPC community XSEDE (more than 500 research projects from different universities).

PI and Co-PIs have developed different kinds of software tools which can utilize the Intel Xeon Phi accelerators in the areas of computational biology, chemistry, astrophysics, coastal science and engineering, etc. For example, PI has explored new application areas, such as deep learning for data sciences, that can utilize the power of Intel Phi and Nvidia GPUs in current HPC environment. And co-PIs developed software tools which have been ported to SuperMIC for Large-scale ligand docking and virtual screening using molecular structure. For Coastal Science and Engineering applications, PIs developed multi-dimensional simulation models to forecast storm surges and hurricane-generated waves.

In order to train and develop professional experts in the areas of HPC applications, the LSU project team hosted training sessions, such as Introduction to Linux,  Introduction to LSU HPC environment 1 & 2, Basic shell scripting, Distributed job execution, Basic OpenMP, Xeon Phi Programming, Introduction to R, Shell scripting, OpenFOAM, Introduction to Python, HPC in Biology, etc., to LSU user groups and external users.
